whistleblowingPolicy.title: Whistleblowing Policy
whistleblowingPolicy.subtitle: Direct Honest Safe International Exchange FZE
whistleblowingPolicy.confidentialNote: All reports will be treated with strict confidentiality.

principles.intro: The Whistleblowing Policy of the Company shall be based on the following principles:
principles.ethicalDescription: All staff shall demonstrate honesty, transparency, integrity, and due care in fulfilling their responsibilities.
principles.goodFaithDescription: The Company encourages staff to report suspected or actual wrongful conduct in good faith.
principles.confidentialityDescription: Sensitivity, discretion, and confidentiality will be given to whistleblowing reports.
principles.noRetaliationDescription: Any form of retaliation against Whistleblowers is strictly prohibited.

reporting.requiredList: Reporting date of the activity, Name of the activity, Details of the involved parties, Details of the suspected allegation, How the issues were detected, Other relevant information
reporting.a: A 'Whistle-blower' shall report any reasonable concern, including but not limited to the events captured in Section 1 of this Policy.
reporting.b: The Company shall set up a dedicated email account to enable the reporting of whistleblowing cases.
reporting.c: The Compliance Function shall undertake the responsibility of managing the account as well as communicating the use of this account to all stakeholders of the Company.
reporting.e: In case the concern is against a Compliance staff, Whistle-blower shall directly send an email to the Chief Internal Audit Officer.
reporting.f: The report shall contain sufficient information to substantiate the concern and to enable a smooth investigation process.
reporting.g: The Compliance Function shall perform an initial review and route the concerns to the relevant stakeholders (Case Manager).
reporting.h: In all cases, a Whistle-blower has the full freedom to report any incident to VARA directly.

investigation.a: Whistleblowing investigations shall be managed by the stakeholders, also called Case Manager, mentioned in Section 3 of this Policy.
investigation.workingGroupList2: Fraud including financial Misconduct - Risk Function
investigation.c: In dealing with suspected misconduct, reasonable care will be taken to avoid baseless allegations, premature notice to persons suspected of misconduct, and disclosure of suspected misconduct to persons not involved with the investigation.
investigation.d: Staff are required to cooperate fully in any official investigation, audit, or similar request.
investigation.e: The investigation process may include meetings with the staff member to discuss the reported concerns. While absolute proof of wrongdoing is not required, the staff member must present reasonable grounds supporting their concerns.
investigation.f: The Case Manager will keep the Whistleblower informed about the status of the reported concern and the approach taken to address it. However, a balance will be maintained between the Whistleblower's legitimate interest in receiving updates and the need to preserve the confidentiality of the investigation process.
investigation.g: If the allegation does not have sufficient evidence or merit, the allegation shall be dismissed. The Whistleblower shall be informed in cases of dismissal and the rationale for dismissal shall be documented for data retention and audit trail.
investigation.timelineDescription: The investigations shall be conducted within (10) working days from the date of the concern being raised. The timeline may vary depending on the nature of the case being considered.

management.a: The Compliance Officer shall oversee the management of all Whistleblowing cases.
management.b: The Compliance Officer shall be responsible for providing all investigation recommendations, unless the concern raised is against a Compliance staff, in which case, the Chief Internal Audit Officer shall be responsible for providing the recommendations.
management.c: The Human Resources representative shall undertake disciplinary actions against the person being investigated if the allegation is found to be true and valid.
management.d: The Compliance Function shall maintain a record of all Whistleblowing cases including those that were dismissed for reporting purposes. They shall exercise due diligence to ensure the accuracy of the reporting by providing all necessary details related to the case reported and attaching all documents evidencing the whistleblowing case.
management.e: The Compliance Officer shall be responsible for the reporting of whistleblowing cases (including dismissed cases) to the CEO on a periodical basis.
management.dataRetentionDescription: Summary details and statistical information and data relating to the types of reports received and corrective measures taken shall be maintained for a minimum of 5 years from the closing of the investigation, except stated otherwise by the local law.

safeguards.protectionList1: A staff who acts as a Whistle-blower is protected against unfair termination and unfair prejudicial employment practices.
safeguards.protectionList2: No adverse action shall be taken against any Whistle-blower in good faith.
safeguards.protectionList3: A staff who has filed a report under this Policy shall be appropriately protected from any negative impact.
safeguards.protectionList4: Appropriate measures shall be taken against anyone under control of the Company, who victimizes (or attempts to) a Whistle-blower.
safeguards.protectionList5: In case a Whistle-blower suspects retaliation, they may raise their concern to the Head of Human Resources.
safeguards.retaliationNotice: Any retaliation, including but not limited to threat of physical harm, loss of job, punitive work assignments, or reduced salary or wages, will be promptly investigated by the 'Working Group'.
safeguards.confidentialityList1: Protected disclosures and investigatory records shall be kept confidential to the extent possible.
safeguards.confidentialityList2: All reports received shall be verified in an appropriate manner and acted upon in confidence.
safeguards.identityProtectionNote: The Company will do its best to protect the identity of the whistle-blower. It must be appreciated that the investigation process may reveal the source of the information.
safeguards.falseAllegationsList1: If a Whistle-blower makes a genuine allegation in good faith which is confirmed as untrue, no action shall be taken against them.
safeguards.falseAllegationsList2: If a Whistle-blower intentionally and knowingly makes false accusations, he/she shall be subject to disciplinary measures or legal action.
safeguards.anonymousDescription: The Company encourages a Whistle-blower to disclose his/ her name in reporting the allegation. Concerns expressed anonymously are much less powerful but will nevertheless be considered.
safeguards.anonymousFactors1: The seriousness of the issues raised
safeguards.anonymousFactors3: The likelihood of confirming the allegation from other sources

training.trainingNote: The Company's staff shall receive training with respect to Whistleblowing as part of the annual mandatory learning modules.
training.awarenessNote: A culture of awareness shall be established across the Company, through periodic communications to all staff via email or verbal communications, flyers/posters, screen displays, and other means, as deemed appropriate by the Company.

introduction.background1: The Company shall be committed towards adhering to the highest standards of governance, openness, transparency, honesty, integrity, accountability and ethical, moral & legal conduct of business operations. The Company shall create an open, transparent and a safe working environment where its staff shall be encouraged to report any irregularities within the Company, in good faith.
introduction.background2: The Whistleblowing right is granted to a staff to speak out when he or she believes that there are good reasons to believe that an instruction received, an operation being studied or, more generally, a situation has arisen that is not compliant with the rules governing the Company.
introduction.background3: All Company staff may exercise their right to whistleblowing in relation to actions they become aware of, either directly or indirectly, in the course of their professional duties. This right must be exercised responsibly and not be misused for purposes of defamation, denigration, or vilification. Any reports received will be investigated confidentially by the designated recipient.
introduction.objectiveA: a) The Whistleblowing Policy ("Policy") aims to enable the Company's staff to report the following incidents:
introduction.objectiveA_list2: Violations of regulations/breach of statutory laws
introduction.objectiveA_list10: Covering up deficiencies in internal controls
introduction.objectiveB_list1: An independent and secure avenue for Whistle-blowers to raise concerns
introduction.objectiveB_list2: Safeguarding and protecting the Whistle-blowers from possible retaliation
introduction.scopeA: a) This Policy is applicable to the Company's Board, Senior Management team, and all its staff (including contractual and seconded staff).
introduction.scopeB: b) This Policy applies exclusively to events and individuals that may cause harm to the Company's staff, the Company itself, or its reputation, and does not extend protections to the Whistleblower personally. Accordingly, any complaints or grievances falling outside this scope shall not be addressed under this Policy.
introduction.governance1: The Policy shall be owned by the Compliance Officer
introduction.governance2: The Policy shall be approved and issued by the Board
introduction.governance3: The Policy shall be reviewed at least annually or as directed by the Board
introduction.governance4: Any exceptions to this Policy shall be approved by the Board
introduction.governance5: Staff shall be notified of material changes to the Policy
introduction.governance6: Any breaches to this Policy shall be escalated to the Compliance Function
introduction.disclaimerNote: This Policy was prepared for the purpose of license application. The content of this Policy may be updated to address the business and regulatory requirements as and when they become available, during the implementation phase of the Company, prior to the launch of the business.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Find answers to common questions about DHS Exchange
faq.a1: DHS Exchange is a Dubai-based crypto exchange built on three values: Direct, Honest, Safe. We provide a secure and compliant platform for spot trading of digital assets under the oversight of VARA.
faq.a2: Yes. DHS Exchange operates under the Dubai Virtual Assets Regulatory Authority (VARA). Our license number will be published on the Public Disclosures page once formally issued.
faq.q3: What makes DHS different from other exchanges?
faq.a3: DHS focuses on three core principles: Direct access, Honest pricing (no hidden fees), and Safe custody of client assets through our partnership with Hextrust.
faq.q4: How do I create an account?
faq.a4: Click Sign Up on the homepage, enter your details, and complete the KYC verification process.
faq.q5: Why do I need to complete KYC?
faq.a5: VARA requires identity verification to prevent money laundering and ensure compliance. This keeps the platform safe for all users.
faq.q6: What documents are required for KYC?
faq.a6: Typically: Government-issued ID (passport, Emirates ID, or driver's license) and Proof of address (utility bill, bank statement, tenancy contract)
faq.a7: Most accounts are verified within 24 hours, provided documents are clear and valid.
faq.a8: Yes. DHS supports AED deposits through regulated banking partners. You can also deposit crypto directly.
faq.a9: Go to your Wallet, select Withdraw, choose the crypto, and follow the instructions. Withdrawal fees are published on our Fees & Charges page.
faq.q10: What are the fees for deposits and withdrawals?
faq.a10: AED withdrawals carry a flat fee, and crypto withdrawals require only blockchain network fees. See the Fees & Charges page for full details.
faq.q11: What types of trading are available?
faq.a11: DHS Exchange currently offers spot trading only. Futures, derivatives, staking, and lending are not currently available under VARA rules.
faq.a12: DHS Exchange provides access to major assets such as BTC, ETH, and USDT, with liquidity sourced from institutional partners.
faq.q13: How do I place an order?
faq.a13: On the Trading Page, choose your pair, select order type (market, limit, stop-limit), enter the amount, and click Buy or Sell.
faq.q14: Is there a minimum trade size?
faq.a14: Yes, the minimum varies by asset. Details are shown on the order form before you confirm.
faq.q15: How are my funds kept safe?
faq.a15: DHS partners with Hextrust, a licensed digital asset custodian. The majority of client assets are held in cold wallets with multi-signature authorization.
faq.q16: Does DHS have insurance for client assets?
faq.a16: Yes, DHS is working with partners to establish custodial insurance coverage. Details will be published on the Custody & Safeguarding page.
faq.q17: How do you protect client data?
faq.a17: We comply with UAE's Data Protection Law (DPL). Data is encrypted, stored securely, and only accessed on a strict need-to-know basis.
faq.q18: What should I do if I have a complaint?
faq.a18: Submit via the Contact Us page or email support. Complaints are acknowledged within 2 business days and resolved within 15 business days.
faq.q19: Can I escalate complaints outside DHS?
faq.a19: Yes. If unresolved internally, clients may escalate to the Dubai Virtual Assets Regulatory Authority (VARA).
faq.q20: How often are your policies updated?
faq.a20: All legal and compliance policies (Risk Disclosure, Privacy, AML/CTF, etc.) are reviewed annually or when regulations change. Updates are announced on the Public Disclosures page.

ctfPolicy.title: Anti-Money Laundering (AML) & Counter-Terrorist Financing (CTF) Policy
ctfPolicy.subtitle: DHS Exchange is committed to protecting the integrity of the financial system by preventing money laundering, terrorist financing, and other illicit activities. Our framework is aligned with VARA regulations, UAE Federal Decree Law No. 20 of 2018 (AML Law), and Federal Decree Law No. 2 of 2019 (Data Protection Law – DPL).

purpose.description: This policy establishes DHS Exchange's standards for identifying, monitoring, and reporting suspicious activity, while safeguarding client data responsibly.

scope.list1: All DHS Exchange operations, staff, and contractors.
scope.list3: All data processing activities related to AML/CTF obligations.

coreMeasures.cdd: Customer Due Diligence (CDD): All customers undergo identity verification (KYC) before accessing services. Enhanced due diligence (EDD) is applied for high-risk clients.
coreMeasures.monitoring: Ongoing Monitoring: Transactions are continuously monitored to detect unusual patterns.
coreMeasures.sanctions: Sanctions Screening: All clients and counterparties are screened against international sanctions and watchlists.
coreMeasures.sar: Suspicious Activity Reporting (SARs): Any suspected money laundering or terrorist financing is reported promptly to UAE authorities and VARA.
coreMeasures.training: Training & Awareness: Staff receive ongoing AML/CTF and compliance training.

dataProtection.description: In line with Federal Decree Law No. 2 of 2019 (DPL) and internal compliance requirements, DHS Exchange commits to:
dataProtection.minimization: Data Minimization: Collect only data necessary for AML/CTF compliance and operational purposes.
dataProtection.consent: Consent: Obtain clear client consent before storing or using personal data.
dataProtection.encryption: Encryption & Backup: Secure all sensitive data using encryption and maintain secure backups.
dataProtection.accessControl: Access Control: Restrict internal access to personal data strictly on a need-to-know basis.
dataProtection.updates: Regular Updates: Review and update privacy notices and data policies regularly.
dataProtection.breachResponse: Breach Response: Maintain protocols for timely detection, response, and reporting of data breaches.
dataProtection.vendorCompliance: Vendor Compliance: Evaluate all software and service providers for compliance with UAE law and VARA standards.

dataRetention.duration: Duration: Personal data will be retained only for as long as necessary to fulfill AML/CTF obligations, as required under UAE law.
dataRetention.purposeLimitation: Purpose Limitation: Data will be used solely for the purpose for which it was collected (compliance, risk management, regulatory reporting).
dataRetention.transparency: Transparency: Clients will be informed of what data is retained, how it will be used, and how long it will be stored.
dataRetention.dataCategories: Data Categories: Different types of data (identity, financial, transactional, communication) will be subject to retention policies specific to business needs and regulatory requirements.

governance.complianceOfficer: Compliance Officer: Responsible for AML/CTF monitoring and reporting.
governance.boardOversight: Board Oversight: The Board reviews AML/CTF controls annually.
governance.policyReview: Policy Review: This policy is reviewed at least once per year, or sooner if required by changes in law or VARA guidance.

complaintPolicy.title: Complaints Handling Policy
complaintPolicy.subtitle: DHS Limited is committed to providing an excellent customer experience and ensuring customer satisfaction with our products and services.

sections.reportingRetention: Reporting of Complaints and Records Retention

introduction.description: DHS Limited ("DHS") is committed to providing an excellent customer experience and ensuring customer satisfaction with our products and services. We have established a Complaints Handling Policy to ensure all complaints and feedback from customers, potential customers and previous customers are handled as effectively as possible. If properly managed, the ongoing information gathering, resolution and analysis of complaints can provide the DHS team with opportunities to gather valuable customer feedback to enhance our products and service and improve customer satisfaction. Our customers are entitled to make a complaint to us and receive responses and resolution in a timely manner. The policy and procedures outlined below describe our process for the handling of verbal and written complaints.

objectiveScope.description: To ensure that all complaints received are handled fairly by the application of a transparent and accessible Complaint Handling Procedures, consistently applied throughout DHS ("the Company"). This policy applies to all past, current and prospective customers of the Company for all products and services offered by the firm in the United Arab Emirates. It sets out the Company's approach with respect to the receipt, recording, acknowledgements, investigation, escalation, resolution and reporting of complaints received from, or on behalf of, existing or past customers.

definedTerms.businessUnitDesc: A product or service group unit inside of DHS.
definedTerms.businessSeniorManagementDesc: A member of the DHS Board of Directors or Director of the relevant business unit.
definedTerms.feedbackDesc: Any customer communication, verbal or written, that is not an expression of dissatisfaction can be recorded and shared internally as a separate information flow from the complaints process. Feedback or inquiry of a non-complaint nature will be recorded and shared as a separate item from complaints that are reported to the regulator.
definedTerms.managementInfoDesc: The reporting of information about customer complaints both from the Complaints log, customer service staff and compliance team investigation, and systems information. The information for any regulatory reports will be shared with the Company's Board of Directors at least monthly.
definedTerms.complaintDefinitionDesc: Any expression of dissatisfaction, whether oral or written, and whether justified or not, on behalf of a customer, with any product or service offered by DHS. This may include:
definedTerms.complaintDefinitionList1: Failure to offer a service, dissatisfaction with the provision or delivery of services, or dissatisfaction with any contact with DHS personnel in connection with provision of a service; or
definedTerms.complaintDefinitionList2: Any complaint involving the possible failure of a product to meet any of the specifications for the product; (b) any dissatisfaction with the design, package or labeling of the product; or (c) any adverse event that may involve the quality of the product, including lack of effect, infection or request for testing.
definedTerms.resolutionDesc: A complaint is considered resolved when the customer has indicated an acceptance of a response by DHS. In most cases, the response or acceptance is required to be in writing. In instances where a complaint is considered minor (secondary in extent, importance, or degree), the response and/or acceptance can be made verbally.

complaintsRegister.description: DHS is required to track all complaints through their entire lifecycle. Compliance will be responsible for ensuring that the responses to customers and management reporting both meet the VARA regulatory reporting requirements. The complaints information should be recorded in a systematic manner so that it can be easily accessed for management and regulatory reporting purposes. It will also enable comparative, thematic and pattern analysis if there are many complaints. Compliance, Risk Management, Finance and Internal Audit will all have access to the log as required for their reviews.

handlingComplaint.websiteAccessDesc: Customers can access DHS Complaint Register on the website: [x] or by email to the following address: [x].
handlingComplaint.emailAccessDesc: Complaints must be acknowledged, by the complaint handler, in writing within 5 working days of receipt of the complaint.
handlingComplaint.step1: All Complaints must be promptly recorded in the Complaints log held in Customer Service by a DHS member of staff.
handlingComplaint.step2: The DHS member of staff must notify the designated Complaints Officer in Customer Service. To this policy, "promptly" means within 24 hours of receipt.
handlingComplaint.step3: The log should indicate whether an acknowledgement and final response will be sent to the customer.
handlingComplaint.step4: The written acknowledgement sent to the customer should meet the following criteria: Confirm receipt of the complaint by DHS, indicate a response or update will be provided within 10 business days, and provide the name, title and contact information of the DHS team member handling the complaint.

responseClosure.resolutionDesc: DHS shall respond in writing to a customer complaint within 20 working days of receiving the complaint, explaining their position and how they propose to deal with the complaint.
responseClosure.criteria1: A complainant has indicated, in writing, their acceptance of the DHS response
responseClosure.criteria2: A complainant has not responded to a resolution letter within 20 working days
responseClosure.criteria3: Where our internal complaint handling procedure has been exhausted

reportingRetention.regulatoryReportingDesc: DHS will submit to the VARA as and when requested, report summarizing the following:
reportingRetention.item3: The number of days it took to acknowledge and to respond to the complaints
reportingRetention.item4: The status of the complaint, including whether resolved or not, and whether redress was provided
reportingRetention.retentionDesc: The regulatory document retention requirements should be strictly adhered to, with retention of complaints records and related resolution information for a minimum of 8 years from the date of receipt of a complaint.

educationTraining.description: DHS must implement a comprehensive training program to ensure that all customer service complaints representatives and related member of staff undergo regular complaints handling awareness training.
educationTraining.tracking1: Training attendance and completion must be tracked on an individual level
educationTraining.tracking2: Overdue training followed up and escalated appropriately
educationTraining.tracking3: The Compliance Officer shall receive reports on overdue and outstanding training on a periodic basis

appendix.description: The appendix contains detailed forms and procedures for complaint handling, including complainant information, complaint details, resolution tracking, and sign-off procedures for complaints officers.
appendix.dateTimeReceived: Date and time complaint was received:
appendix.writtenDetails: Has complainant been asked to provide details in writing?
appendix.writtenDetailsNote: *(if no, this is to be requested before action can be taken)
appendix.materialNature: Is the complaint material in nature?
appendix.customerType: Is the complaint from a historic or new customer?
appendix.timescaleAgreed: Has a timescale to resolve the complaint been agreed with the complainant? If so, by when?
appendix.notifiedOfficer: If the answer to either question above is Yes, Has the complaint been notified to the Complaints Officer
appendix.complaintResolved: Has the complaint been resolved? (provide brief details)
appendix.proceduralChanges: Are any procedural changes necessary to avoid recurrence of the matter complained of?
appendix.changesImplemented: If yes, have these changes have been implemented? (provide brief details)
appendix.confirmation: I confirm the complaint has been treated in accordance with our procedures.

hero.title: Token Listing & Asset Admission Policy
hero.description: DHS Exchange is committed to ensuring that all digital assets available for trading meet regulatory standards, security requirements, and transparency obligations under the Dubai Virtual Assets Regulatory Authority (VARA).

purpose.title: 1. Purpose
purpose.desc: This policy sets out the principles and procedures DHS Exchange applies when admitting a new token or virtual asset for trading. The aim is to protect clients, ensure market integrity, and comply with VARA regulations.

criteria.title: 2. Admission Criteria
criteria.intro: Before any token is listed, DHS Exchange evaluates the following factors:
criteria.item1: Regulatory Compliance: Token must not be prohibited under UAE law or VARA guidance.
criteria.item2: Security Review: Smart contract audits (if applicable) and protocol security assessments.
criteria.item3: Market Demand: Liquidity, trading volume, and relevance to DHS clients.
criteria.item4: Transparency: Availability of clear information on token issuance, supply, and governance.
criteria.item5: Risk Assessment: Consideration of volatility, concentration risks, and potential for market manipulation.

disclosure.title: 3. Information Disclosure
disclosure.intro: For each listed token, DHS Exchange will provide clients with:
disclosure.item3: Circulating and total supply (with % in circulation)
disclosure.item5: Smart contract audit status and date (if applicable)

monitoring.title: 4. Ongoing Monitoring
monitoring.intro1: Tokens are subject to continuous review to ensure they remain compliant and aligned with DHS standards.
monitoring.intro2: DHS may suspend or delist any token if:
monitoring.item4: The project fails to maintain transparency with its community

liquidity.title: 5. Liquidity Provision
liquidity.desc: DHS Exchange integrates liquidity from institutional partners (Binance, Crypto.com,…) while ensuring full VARA compliance. This approach guarantees deep liquidity, reliable pricing, and best execution for clients.

protection.title: 6. Client Protection
protection.desc: DHS Exchange does not guarantee the future value of any token and reminds clients that digital assets are volatile and high-risk investments.

review.title: 7. Policy Review
review.desc: This policy will be reviewed annually or as required by VARA. Updates will be published on the DHS website.

We follow a Direct, Honest, Safe approach, ensuring confidentiality, integrity, and resilience of information in compliance with the Dubai Virtual Assets Regulatory Authority (VARA) and the UAE's Federal Decree Law No. 2 of 2019 (DPL).

dataProtectionPrinciples.title: Data Protection Principles
dataProtectionPrinciples.subtitle: DHS Exchange applies the following principles to all personal and transactional data

dataMinimization.title: Data Minimization
dataMinimization.description: We collect only what is necessary to operate and comply with regulatory obligations.

consent.title: Consent
consent.description: Clients must provide informed consent before data is stored or processed.

purposeLimitation.title: Purpose Limitation
purposeLimitation.description: Data is used strictly for regulatory, operational, and security purposes.

transparency.title: Transparency
transparency.description: Clients are informed about what data is collected, how it is used, and retention periods.

dataSecurityMeasures.title: Data Security Measures
dataSecurityMeasures.subtitle: Comprehensive protection for all client information

points.encryption: Encryption: Sensitive information is encrypted both in transit and at rest.
points.backups: Backups: Critical data is securely backed up and tested regularly for recovery.
points.accessControl: Access Control: Internal access to data is strictly limited on a need-to-know basis.
points.vendorCompliance: Vendor Compliance: All third-party providers are evaluated for regulatory and security compliance.

dataRetention.title: Data Retention & Storage Limitation
dataRetention.subtitle: Compliance with UAE and VARA regulations

points.lawDuration: Data is retained only for the duration required by law (AML/CTF obligations, VARA rules).
points.federalDecree: Retention follows Federal Decree Law No. 2 of 2019 (DPL): limited to specific purposes and disclosed to clients.
points.categories: Different categories of data (identity, financial, transactional) follow separate retention policies.

monitoring.title: 24/7 Monitoring
monitoring.description: Systems are monitored continuously for fraud and anomalies.

incidentResponse.title: Incident Response
incidentResponse.description: DHS maintains protocols for immediate detection, escalation, and response to breaches.

resilienceTesting.title: Resilience Testing
resilienceTesting.description: Regular penetration tests and audits are performed by independent experts.

assetSegregation.title: Asset Segregation

points.requestInfo: Clients may request information on their stored data.
points.corrections: Clients have the right to request corrections or, where legally possible, deletion of their personal data.
points.noSharing: DHS Exchange ensures that no client data is shared with unauthorized third parties.

points.regularUpdates: Privacy notices and data protection policies are updated regularly.
points.advanceDisclosure: Any material changes to our cybersecurity or data protection practices will be disclosed to clients in advance.
